fields.name: broadcast
fields.description:
Override `[runtime]` configurations in a running workflow.

Uses for broadcast include making temporary changes to task
behaviour, and task-to-downstream-task communication via
environment variables.

A broadcast can set/override any `[runtime]` configuration for all
cycles or for a specific cycle. If a task is affected by
specific-cycle and all-cycle broadcasts at the same time, the
specific takes precedence.

Broadcasts can also target all tasks, specific tasks or families of
tasks. If a task is affected by broadcasts to multiple ancestor
namespaces (tasks it inherits from), the result is determined by
normal `[runtime]` inheritance.

Broadcasts are applied at the time of job submission.

Broadcasts persist, even across restarts. Broadcasts made to
specific cycle points will expire when the cycle point is older
than the oldest active cycle point in the workflow.

Active broadcasts can be revoked using the "clear" mode.
Any broadcasts matching the specified cycle points and
namespaces will be revoked.

Note: a "clear" broadcast for a specific cycle or namespace does
*not* clear all-cycle or all-namespace broadcasts.
 Valid for: paused, running workflows.

args.name: cutoff
args.description: Clear broadcasts earlier than cutoff cycle point. (for use with "Expire" mode).

args.name: cyclePoints
args.description:
List of cycle points to target (or `*` to cancel all all-cycle
broadcasts without canceling all specific-cycle broadcasts).

args.name: mode
args.description: What type of broadcast is this?

args.name: namespaces
args.description: List of namespaces (tasks or families) to target.

args.name: settings
args.description:
The `[runtime]` configuration to override with this broadcast
(e.g. `script = true` or `[environment]ANSWER=42`).

fields.name: extTrigger
fields.description:
Report an external event message to a scheduler.

External triggers allow any program to send
messages to the Cylc scheduler. Cylc can use such
messages as signals that an external prerequisite has
been satisfied.

The ID argument should be unique to each external
trigger event. When an incoming message satisfies
a task's external trigger the message ID is broadcast
to all downstream tasks in the cycle point as
``$CYLC_EXT_TRIGGER_ID``.  Tasks can use
``$CYLC_EXT_TRIGGER_ID``, for example,  to
identify a new data file that the external
triggering system is responding to.

Use the retry options in case the target workflow is down or out of
contact.

Note: To manually trigger a task use "Trigger" not
"ExtTrigger".

args.name: id
args.description: Unique trigger ID.

args.name: message
args.description: External trigger message.

fields.name: message
fields.description:
Record task messages.

Send messages to:
- The job stdout/stderr.
- The job status file, if there is one.
- The scheduler, if communication is possible.

Jobs use this to record and report status such
as success and failure. Applications run by jobs can use
this command to report messages and to report registered task
outputs.

args.name: messages
args.description: List in the form `[[severity, message], ...]`.

fields.name: pause
fields.description:
Pause a workflow.

This suspends submission of tasks.

fields.name: reload
fields.description:
Reload the configuration of a running workflow.

All settings including task definitions, with the exception of
workflow log config, can be changed on reload. Changes to task
definitions take effect immediately, unless a task is already
running at reload time.

If the workflow was started with Jinja2 template variables on the
command line (cylc play --set "FOO='bar'" REG) the same template
settings apply to the reload (only changes to the flow.cylc
file itself are reloaded).

If the modified workflow config does not parse, failure to reload
will be reported but no harm will be done to the running workflow.

fields.name: resume
fields.description:
Resume a paused workflow.

See also the opposite command `pause`.

fields.name: setVerbosity
fields.description:
Change the logging severity level of a running workflow.

Only messages at or above the chosen severity level will be logged;
for example, if you choose `WARNING`, only warnings and critical
messages will be logged.

fields.name: setGraphWindowExtent
fields.description:
Set the maximum graph distance (n) from an active node
of the data-store graph window.

fields.name: stop
fields.description:
Tell a workflow to shut down or stop a specified
flow from spawning any further.

By default stopping workflows wait for submitted and running tasks
to complete before shutting down. You can change this behaviour
with the "mode" option.

Tasks that become ready after the shutdown is ordered will be
submitted immediately if the workflow is restarted.
Remaining task event handlers, job poll and kill commands, will
be executed prior to shutdown, unless
the stop mode is `Now`.

args.name: clockTime
args.description: Stop after wall-clock time passes this point.

args.name: cyclePoint
args.description: Stop after the workflow reaches this cycle.

args.name: flowNum
args.description: Number of flow to stop.

args.name: task
args.description: Stop after this task succeeds.

fields.name: setHoldPoint
fields.description:
Set workflow hold after cycle point. All tasks after this point
will be held.

args.name: point
args.description: Hold all tasks after the specified cycle point.

fields.name: releaseHoldPoint
fields.description:
Release all tasks and unset the workflow hold point, if set.

Held tasks do not submit their jobs even if ready to run.

fields.name: hold
fields.description:
Hold tasks within a workflow.

Held tasks do not submit their jobs even if ready to run.

fields.name: poll
fields.description:
Poll (query) jobs to verify and update their statuses.

This checks the job status file and queries the
job runner on the job platform.

Pollable tasks are those in the n=0 window with
an associated job ID, including incomplete finished
tasks.

fields.name: release
fields.description:
Release held tasks within a workflow.

See also the opposite command `hold`.

fields.name: remove
fields.description: Remove one or more task instances from a running workflow.

fields.name: setOutputs
fields.description:
Artificially mark task outputs as completed.

This allows you to manually intervene with Cylc's scheduling
algorithm by artificially satisfying outputs of tasks.

By default this makes tasks appear as if they succeeded.

args.name: outputs
args.description: List of task outputs to satisfy.

fields.name: trigger
fields.description:
Manually trigger tasks.

Warning: waiting tasks that are queue-limited will be queued if
triggered, to submit as normal when released by the queue; queued
tasks will submit immediately if triggered, even if that violates
the queue limit (so you may need to trigger a queue-limited task
twice to get it to submit immediately).

args.name: flow
args.description:
The flow(s) to trigger these tasks in.

This should be a list of flow numbers OR a single-item list
containing one of the following three strings:

* all - Triggered tasks belong to all active flows
  (default).
* new - Triggered tasks are assigned to a new flow.
* none - Triggered tasks do not belong to any flow.

args.name: flowDescr
args.description:
If starting a new flow, this field can be used to provide the
new flow with a description for later reference.

args.name: flowWait
args.description:
Should the workflow "wait" or "continue on" from this task?

If `false` the scheduler will spawn and run downstream tasks
as normal (default).

If `true` the scheduler will not spawn the downstream tasks
unless it has been caught by the same flow at a later time.

For example you might set this to True to trigger a task
ahead of a flow, where you don't want the scheduled to
"continue on" from this task until the flow has caught up
with it.

fields.name: play
fields.description: Start, resume or restart a workflow run.

args.name: abortIfAnyTaskFails
args.description: If set workflow will abort with status 1 if any task fails.

args.name: cylcVersion
args.description: Set the Cylc version that the workflow starts with.

args.name: debug
args.description: Output developer information and show exception tracebacks.

args.name: finalCyclePoint
args.description:
Set the final cycle point. This command line option overrides
the workflow config option `[scheduling]final cycle point`.

args.name: holdCyclePoint
args.description: Hold all tasks after this cycle point.

args.name: host
args.description:
Specify the host on which to start-up the workflow. If not
specified, a host will be selected using the
`[scheduler]run hosts` global config.

args.name: initialCyclePoint
args.description:
Set the initial cycle point.

Required if not defined in flow.cylc.

args.name: mainLoop
args.description:
Specify an additional plugin to run in the main loop. These
are used in combination with those specified in
`[scheduler][main loop]plugins`. Can be used multiple times.

args.name: noTimestamp
args.description: Don't timestamp logged messages.

args.name: pause
args.description: Pause workflow immediately on starting.

args.name: set
args.description:
Set the value of a Jinja2 template variable in the workflow
definition. Values should be valid Python literals so strings
must be quoted e.g. `STR="string"`, `INT=43`, `BOOL=True`.
This option can be used multiple  times on the command line.
NOTE: these settings persist across workflow restarts, but can
be set again on the `cylc play` command line if they need to be
overridden.

args.name: setFile
args.description:
Set the value of Jinja2 template variables in the workflow
definition from a file containing NAME=VALUE pairs (one per
line). As with "set" values should be valid Python literals so
strings must be quoted e.g.  `STR='string'`. NOTE: these
settings persist across workflow restarts, but can be set again
on the `cylc play` command line if they need to be overridden.

args.name: startCyclePoint
args.description:
Set the start cycle point, which may be after the initial cycle
point.

If the specified start point is not in the sequence, the next
on-sequence point will be used.

(Not to be confused with the initial cycle point).

This replaces the Cylc 7 --warm option.

args.name: stopCyclePoint
args.description:
Set the stop cycle point. Shut down after all tasks have PASSED
this cycle point. (Not to be confused with the final cycle
point.) This command line option overrides the workflow config
option `[scheduling]stop after cycle point`.

fields.name: clean
fields.description: Clean a workflow from the run directory.

args.name: localOnly
args.description: Only clean on the local filesystem (not remote hosts).

args.name: remoteOnly
args.description: Only clean on remote hosts (not the local filesystem).

args.name: rm
args.description:
Only clean the specified subdirectories or files in
the run directory, rather than the whole run.

A colon separated list that accepts globs,
e.g. ``.service/db:log:share:work/2020*``.

types.name: Queries
types.description: Multi-Workflow root level queries.

args.name: states
args.description: List of task states to show

args.name: ids
args.description:
Node IDs, cycle point and/or-just family/task namespace:
    ["1234/foo", "1234/FAM", "*/FAM"]

types.name: ID
types.description: The `ID` scalar type represents a unique identifier, often used to refetch an object or as key for a cache. The ID type appears in a JSON response as a String; however, it is not intended to be human-readable. When expected as an input type, any string (such as `"4"`) or integer (such as `4`) input value will be accepted as an ID.

types.name: String
types.description: The `String` scalar type represents textual data, represented as UTF-8 character sequences. The String type is most often used by GraphQL to represent free-form human-readable text.

types.name: Int
types.description: The `Int` scalar type represents non-fractional signed whole numeric values. Int can represent values between -(2^31 - 1) and 2^31 - 1 since represented in JSON as double-precision floating point numbers specifiedby [IEEE 754](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IEEE_floating_point).

types.name: Task
types.description: Task definition, static fields

args.name: stripNull
args.description: A flag that when enabled strips out those fields not set in the protobuf object. And when this flag is disabled the default values of Protobuf fields are provided (boolean=false, list=[], string="".

args.name: stripNull
args.description: A flag that when enabled strips out those fields not set in the protobuf object. And when this flag is disabled the default values of Protobuf fields are provided (boolean=false, list=[], string="".

args.name: stripNull
args.description: A flag that when enabled strips out those fields not set in the protobuf object. And when this flag is disabled the default values of Protobuf fields are provided (boolean=false, list=[], string="".

types.name: NodeMeta
types.description:
Meta data fields,
including custom fields in a generic user-defined dump

types.name: GenericScalar
types.description:
The `GenericScalar` scalar type represents a generic
GraphQL scalar value that could be:
String, Boolean, Int, Float, List or Object.

types.name: Runtime
types.description:
Subset of runtime fields.

Existing on 3 different node types:
- Task/family definition (from the flow.cylc file)
- Task/family cycle instance (includes any broadcasts on top
  of the definition)
- Job (a record of what was run for a particular submit)

types.name: RuntimeSetting
types.description: Key = val setting, e.g. for [runtime][X][environment]

types.name: Float
types.description: The `Float` scalar type represents signed double-precision fractional values as specified by [IEEE 754](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IEEE_floating_point).

types.name: TaskProxy
types.description: Task cycle instance.

See also the opposite command `pause`.

fields.name: setVerbosity
fields.description:
Change the logging severity level of a running workflow.

Only messages at or above the chosen severity level will be logged;
for example, if you choose `WARNING`, only warnings and critical
messages will be logged.

fields.name: setGraphWindowExtent
fields.description:
Set the maximum graph distance (n) from an active node
of the data-store graph window.

fields.name: stop
fields.description:
Tell a workflow to shut down or stop a specified
flow from spawning any further.

By default stopping workflows wait for submitted and running tasks
to complete before shutting down. You can change this behaviour
with the "mode" option.

Tasks that become ready after the shutdown is ordered will be
submitted immediately if the workflow is restarted.
Remaining task event handlers, job poll and kill commands, will
be executed prior to shutdown, unless
the stop mode is `Now`.

args.name: clockTime
args.description: Stop after wall-clock time passes this point.

args.name: cyclePoint
args.description: Stop after the workflow reaches this cycle.

args.name: flowNum
args.description: Number of flow to stop.

args.name: task
args.description: Stop after this task succeeds.

fields.name: setHoldPoint
fields.description:
Set workflow hold after cycle point. All tasks after this point
will be held.

args.name: point
args.description: Hold all tasks after the specified cycle point.

fields.name: releaseHoldPoint
fields.description:
Release all tasks and unset the workflow hold point, if set.

Held tasks do not submit their jobs even if ready to run.

fields.name: hold
fields.description:
Hold tasks within a workflow.

Held tasks do not submit their jobs even if ready to run.

fields.name: poll
fields.description:
Poll (query) jobs to verify and update their statuses.

This checks the job status file and queries the
job runner on the job platform.

Pollable tasks are those in the n=0 window with
an associated job ID, including incomplete finished
tasks.

fields.name: release
fields.description:
Release held tasks within a workflow.

See also the opposite command `hold`.

fields.name: remove
fields.description: Remove one or more task instances from a running workflow.

fields.name: setOutputs
fields.description:
Artificially mark task outputs as completed.

This allows you to manually intervene with Cylc's scheduling
algorithm by artificially satisfying outputs of tasks.

By default this makes tasks appear as if they succeeded.

args.name: outputs
args.description: List of task outputs to satisfy.

fields.name: trigger
fields.description:
Manually trigger tasks.

Warning: waiting tasks that are queue-limited will be queued if
triggered, to submit as normal when released by the queue; queued
tasks will submit immediately if triggered, even if that violates
the queue limit (so you may need to trigger a queue-limited task
twice to get it to submit immediately).

args.name: flow
args.description:
The flow(s) to trigger these tasks in.

This should be a list of flow numbers OR a single-item list
containing one of the following three strings:

* all - Triggered tasks belong to all active flows
  (default).
* new - Triggered tasks are assigned to a new flow.
* none - Triggered tasks do not belong to any flow.

args.name: flowDescr
args.description:
If starting a new flow, this field can be used to provide the
new flow with a description for later reference.

args.name: flowWait
args.description:
Should the workflow "wait" or "continue on" from this task?

If `false` the scheduler will spawn and run downstream tasks
as normal (default).

If `true` the scheduler will not spawn the downstream tasks
unless it has been caught by the same flow at a later time.

For example you might set this to True to trigger a task
ahead of a flow, where you don't want the scheduled to
"continue on" from this task until the flow has caught up
with it.

fields.name: play
fields.description: Start, resume or restart a workflow run.

args.name: abortIfAnyTaskFails
args.description: If set workflow will abort with status 1 if any task fails.

args.name: cylcVersion
args.description: Set the Cylc version that the workflow starts with.

args.name: debug
args.description: Output developer information and show exception tracebacks.

args.name: finalCyclePoint
args.description:
Set the final cycle point. This command line option overrides
the workflow config option `[scheduling]final cycle point`.

args.name: holdCyclePoint
args.description: Hold all tasks after this cycle point.

args.name: host
args.description:
Specify the host on which to start-up the workflow. If not
specified, a host will be selected using the
`[scheduler]run hosts` global config.

args.name: initialCyclePoint
args.description:
Set the initial cycle point.

Required if not defined in flow.cylc.

args.name: mainLoop
args.description:
Specify an additional plugin to run in the main loop. These
are used in combination with those specified in
`[scheduler][main loop]plugins`. Can be used multiple times.

args.name: noTimestamp
args.description: Don't timestamp logged messages.

args.name: pause
args.description: Pause workflow immediately on starting.

args.name: set
args.description:
Set the value of a Jinja2 template variable in the workflow
definition. Values should be valid Python literals so strings
must be quoted e.g. `STR="string"`, `INT=43`, `BOOL=True`.
This option can be used multiple  times on the command line.
NOTE: these settings persist across workflow restarts, but can
be set again on the `cylc play` command line if they need to be
overridden.

args.name: setFile
args.description:
Set the value of Jinja2 template variables in the workflow
definition from a file containing NAME=VALUE pairs (one per
line). As with "set" values should be valid Python literals so
strings must be quoted e.g.  `STR='string'`. NOTE: these
settings persist across workflow restarts, but can be set again
on the `cylc play` command line if they need to be overridden.

args.name: startCyclePoint
args.description:
Set the start cycle point, which may be after the initial cycle
point.

If the specified start point is not in the sequence, the next
on-sequence point will be used.

(Not to be confused with the initial cycle point).

This replaces the Cylc 7 --warm option.

args.name: stopCyclePoint
args.description:
Set the stop cycle point. Shut down after all tasks have PASSED
this cycle point. (Not to be confused with the final cycle
point.) This command line option overrides the workflow config
option `[scheduling]stop after cycle point`.

fields.name: clean
fields.description: Clean a workflow from the run directory.

args.name: localOnly
args.description: Only clean on the local filesystem (not remote hosts).

args.name: remoteOnly
args.description: Only clean on remote hosts (not the local filesystem).

args.name: rm
args.description:
Only clean the specified subdirectories or files in
the run directory, rather than the whole run.

A colon separated list that accepts globs,
e.g. ``.service/db:log:share:work/2020*``.

types.name: Broadcast
types.description:
Override `[runtime]` configurations in a running workflow.

Uses for broadcast include making temporary changes to task
behaviour, and task-to-downstream-task communication via
environment variables.

A broadcast can set/override any `[runtime]` configuration for all
cycles or for a specific cycle. If a task is affected by
specific-cycle and all-cycle broadcasts at the same time, the
specific takes precedence.

Broadcasts can also target all tasks, specific tasks or families of
tasks. If a task is affected by broadcasts to multiple ancestor
namespaces (tasks it inherits from), the result is determined by
normal `[runtime]` inheritance.

Broadcasts are applied at the time of job submission.

Broadcasts persist, even across restarts. Broadcasts made to
specific cycle points will expire when the cycle point is older
than the oldest active cycle point in the workflow.

Active broadcasts can be revoked using the "clear" mode.
Any broadcasts matching the specified cycle points and
namespaces will be revoked.

Note: a "clear" broadcast for a specific cycle or namespace does
*not* clear all-cycle or all-namespace broadcasts.

types.name: CyclePoint
types.description: An integer or date-time cyclepoint.

types.name: BroadcastCyclePoint
types.description: A cycle point or `*`.

enumValues.name: Set
enumValues.description: Create a new broadcast.

enumValues.name: Clear
enumValues.description: Clear existing broadcasts globally or for specified cycle points and namespaces if provided.

enumValues.name: Expire
enumValues.description: Clear all broadcasts for cycle points earlier than the provided cutoff.

types.name: NamespaceName
types.description: The name of a task or family.

types.name: BroadcastSetting
types.description:
A `[runtime]` configuration for a namespace.

Should be a `key=value` pair where sections are wrapped with square
brackets.

Examples:
    script=true
    [environment]ANSWER=42

Nested sections should only have one set of square brackets e.g:

    [section][subsection][subsubsection]=value

types.name: WorkflowID
types.description: A registered workflow.

types.name: ExtTrigger
types.description:
Report an external event message to a scheduler.

External triggers allow any program to send
messages to the Cylc scheduler. Cylc can use such
messages as signals that an external prerequisite has
been satisfied.

The ID argument should be unique to each external
trigger event. When an incoming message satisfies
a task's external trigger the message ID is broadcast
to all downstream tasks in the cycle point as
``$CYLC_EXT_TRIGGER_ID``.  Tasks can use
``$CYLC_EXT_TRIGGER_ID``, for example,  to
identify a new data file that the external
triggering system is responding to.

Use the retry options in case the target workflow is down or out of
contact.

Note: To manually trigger a task use "Trigger" not
"ExtTrigger".

types.name: Message
types.description:
Record task messages.

Send messages to:
- The job stdout/stderr.
- The job status file, if there is one.
- The scheduler, if communication is possible.

Jobs use this to record and report status such
as success and failure. Applications run by jobs can use
this command to report messages and to report registered task
outputs.

types.name: Pause
types.description:
Pause a workflow.

This suspends submission of tasks.

types.name: Reload
types.description:
Reload the configuration of a running workflow.

All settings including task definitions, with the exception of
workflow log config, can be changed on reload. Changes to task
definitions take effect immediately, unless a task is already
running at reload time.

If the workflow was started with Jinja2 template variables on the
command line (cylc play --set "FOO='bar'" REG) the same template
settings apply to the reload (only changes to the flow.cylc
file itself are reloaded).

If the modified workflow config does not parse, failure to reload
will be reported but no harm will be done to the running workflow.

types.name: Resume
types.description:
Resume a paused workflow.

See also the opposite command `pause`.

types.name: SetVerbosity
types.description:
Change the logging severity level of a running workflow.

Only messages at or above the chosen severity level will be logged;
for example, if you choose `WARNING`, only warnings and critical
messages will be logged.

enumValues.name: CRITICAL
enumValues.description: Python logging level: CRITICAL = 50.

enumValues.name: FATAL
enumValues.description: Python logging level: CRITICAL = 50.

enumValues.name: ERROR
enumValues.description: Python logging level: ERROR = 40.

enumValues.name: WARN
enumValues.description: Python logging level: WARN = 30.

enumValues.name: WARNING
enumValues.description: Python logging level: WARN = 30.

enumValues.name: INFO
enumValues.description: Python logging level: INFO = 20.

enumValues.name: DEBUG
enumValues.description: Python logging level: DEBUG = 10.

enumValues.name: NOTSET
enumValues.description: Python logging level: NOTSET = 0.

types.name: SetGraphWindowExtent
types.description:
Set the maximum graph distance (n) from an active node
of the data-store graph window.

types.name: Stop
types.description:
Tell a workflow to shut down or stop a specified
flow from spawning any further.

By default stopping workflows wait for submitted and running tasks
to complete before shutting down. You can change this behaviour
with the "mode" option.

Tasks that become ready after the shutdown is ordered will be
submitted immediately if the workflow is restarted.
Remaining task event handlers, job poll and kill commands, will
be executed prior to shutdown, unless
the stop mode is `Now`.

types.name: TimePoint
types.description: A date-time in the ISO8601 format.

types.name: WorkflowStopMode
types.description: The mode used to stop a running workflow.

enumValues.name: Clean
enumValues.description:
Regular shutdown:
* Wait for all active jobs to complete.
* Run workflow event handlers and wait for them to complete.

enumValues.name: Kill
enumValues.description:
Kill shutdown:
* Wait for all active jobs to be killed.
* Run workflow event handlers and wait for them to complete.

enumValues.name: Now
enumValues.description:
Immediate shutdown
* Don't kill submitted or running jobs.
* Run workflow event handlers and wait for them to complete.

enumValues.name: NowNow
enumValues.description:
Immediate shutdown
* Don't kill submitted or running jobs.
* Don't run event handlers.

types.name: TaskID
types.description: The name of an active task.

types.name: SetHoldPoint
types.description:
Set workflow hold after cycle point. All tasks after this point
will be held.

types.name: ReleaseHoldPoint
types.description:
Release all tasks and unset the workflow hold point, if set.

Held tasks do not submit their jobs even if ready to run.

types.name: Hold
types.description:
Hold tasks within a workflow.

Held tasks do not submit their jobs even if ready to run.

types.name: NamespaceIDGlob
types.description:
A glob search for an active task or family.

Can use the wildcard character (`*`), e.g `foo*` might match `foot`.

types.name: Kill
types.description: Kill running or submitted jobs.

types.name: Poll
types.description:
Poll (query) jobs to verify and update their statuses.

This checks the job status file and queries the
job runner on the job platform.

Pollable tasks are those in the n=0 window with
an associated job ID, including incomplete finished
tasks.

types.name: Release
types.description:
Release held tasks within a workflow.

See also the opposite command `hold`.

types.name: Remove
types.description: Remove one or more task instances from a running workflow.

types.name: SetOutputs
types.description:
Artificially mark task outputs as completed.

This allows you to manually intervene with Cylc's scheduling
algorithm by artificially satisfying outputs of tasks.

By default this makes tasks appear as if they succeeded.

types.name: Trigger
types.description:
Manually trigger tasks.

Warning: waiting tasks that are queue-limited will be queued if
triggered, to submit as normal when released by the queue; queued
tasks will submit immediately if triggered, even if that violates
the queue limit (so you may need to trigger a queue-limited task
twice to get it to submit immediately).

types.name: Flow
types.description: An integer or one of all, new or none.

types.name: Play
types.description: Start, resume or restart a workflow run.

types.name: CylcVersion
types.description: A Cylc version identifier e.g. 8.0.0

types.name: RunMode
types.description: The mode to run a workflow in.

enumValues.name: Live
enumValues.description: The normal default run mode

enumValues.name: Dummy
enumValues.description: Replaces all *-script items with nothing

enumValues.name: DummyLocal
enumValues.description: Replaces all *-script items with nothing and sets platform = localhost for all tasks.

enumValues.name: Simulation
enumValues.description: Simulates job submission, does not run anything at all.

types.name: Clean
types.description: Clean a workflow from the run directory.

types.name: Subscriptions
types.description: Multi-Workflow root level subscriptions.

fields.name: deltas
fields.description: Grouped deltas of the WFS publish

args.name: workflows
args.description: List of full ID, i.e. `~user/workflow_id`

types.name: Deltas
types.description: Grouped deltas of the WFS publish

fields.name: pruned
fields.description: WFS Nodes/Edges that have been removed.

types.name: Added
types.description: Added node/edge deltas.

types.name: Delta
types.description:
Interface for delta types.

Since we usually subscribe to the same fields for both added/updated
deltas this interface makes writing fragments easier.

NOTE: This interface is specialised to the "added" type, other types must
override fields as required.

types.name: Updated
types.description: Updated node/edge deltas.

types.name: Pruned
types.description: WFS Nodes/Edges that have been removed.

types.name: __Schema
types.description: A GraphQL Schema defines the capabilities of a GraphQL server. It exposes all available types and directives on the server, as well as the entry points for query, mutation and subscription operations.

fields.name: types
fields.description: A list of all types supported by this server.

fields.name: queryType
fields.description: The type that query operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: mutationType
fields.description: If this server supports mutation, the type that mutation operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: subscriptionType
fields.description: If this server support subscription, the type that subscription operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: directives
fields.description: A list of all directives supported by this server.

types.name: __Type
types.description:
The fundamental unit of any GraphQL Schema is the type. There are many kinds of types in GraphQL as represented by the `__TypeKind` enum.

Depending on the kind of a type, certain fields describe information about that type. Scalar types provide no information beyond a name and description, while Enum types provide their values. Object and Interface types provide the fields they describe. Abstract types, Union and Interface, provide the Object types possible at runtime. List and NonNull types compose other types.

types.name: __TypeKind
types.description: An enum describing what kind of type a given `__Type` is

enumValues.name: SCALAR
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a scalar.

enumValues.name: OBJECT
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an object. `fields` and `interfaces` are valid fields.

enumValues.name: INTERFACE
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an interface. `fields` and `possibleTypes` are valid fields.

enumValues.name: UNION
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a union. `possibleTypes` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: ENUM
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an enum. `enumValues` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: INPUT_OBJECT
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an input object. `inputFields` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: LIST
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a list. `ofType` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: NON_NULL
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a non-null. `ofType` is a valid field.

types.name: __Field
types.description: Object and Interface types are described by a list of Fields, each of which has a name, potentially a list of arguments, and a return type.

types.name: __InputValue
types.description: Arguments provided to Fields or Directives and the input fields of an InputObject are represented as Input Values which describe their type and optionally a default value.

types.name: __EnumValue
types.description: One possible value for a given Enum. Enum values are unique values, not a placeholder for a string or numeric value. However an Enum value is returned in a JSON response as a string.

types.name: __Directive
types.description:
A Directive provides a way to describe alternate runtime execution and type validation behavior in a GraphQL document.

In some cases, you need to provide options to alter GraphQL's execution behavior in ways field arguments will not suffice, such as conditionally including or skipping a field. Directives provide this by describing additional information to the executor.

types.name: __DirectiveLocation
types.description: A Directive can be adjacent to many parts of the GraphQL language, a __DirectiveLocation describes one such possible adjacencies.

enumValues.name: QUERY
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a query operation.

enumValues.name: MUTATION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a mutation operation.

enumValues.name: SUBSCRIPTION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a subscription operation.

enumValues.name: FIELD
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a field.

enumValues.name: FRAGMENT_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a fragment definition.

enumValues.name: FRAGMENT_SPREAD
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a fragment spread.

enumValues.name: INLINE_FRAGMENT
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an inline fragment.

enumValues.name: SCHEMA
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a schema definition.

enumValues.name: SCALAR
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a scalar definition.

enumValues.name: OBJECT
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an object definition.

enumValues.name: FIELD_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a field definition.

enumValues.name: ARGUMENT_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an argument definition.

enumValues.name: INTERFACE
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an interface definition.

enumValues.name: UNION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a union definition.

enumValues.name: ENUM
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an enum definition.

enumValues.name: ENUM_VALUE
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an enum value definition.

enumValues.name: INPUT_OBJECT
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an input object definition.

enumValues.name: INPUT_FIELD_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an input object field definition.
